I'm 30 years old and I was running my first marathon today. Around mile 18, I got
hit with the most intense headache I've ever experienced — sudden onset, like something
popped in my head. I had to stop running immediately. The headache is a 9 out of 10,
concentrated at the back of my head and neck. I also feel nauseous and the light is
really bothering me. I've never had a headache this severe before. I'm sitting at the
medical tent at the race and they gave me some water. Could this be an exertional
headache from the marathon?

This is **not something to assume is a benign exertional headache**. A **sudden, “worst headache of your life,” like something popped**, with **9/10 pain**, **back of head/neck pain**, **nausea**, and **light sensitivity** during exertion is a **medical emergency** until proven otherwise (concerns include **subarachnoid hemorrhage/brain bleed**, **artery dissection**, or other dangerous causes). You need **immediate emergency evaluation and brain imaging**.

### What to do right now (do not keep waiting it out)
- **Tell the medical tent staff immediately**: “I have a sudden thunderclap worst headache of my life with neck pain, nausea, and photophobia. I need EMS to the ER now.”
- **Ask them to call 911 / activate EMS** for transport to an **Emergency Department** (do not drive yourself).
- **Do not resume running**. Stay seated/lying down as they advise.
- Avoid taking more meds unless a clinician on site directs you—some pain meds can complicate bleeding risk.

### Why this is urgent
Exertional headaches can happen, but **first-time, sudden-onset, maximal-severity headache**—especially with **neck pain**—must be treated as a possible **brain bleed or vascular event** until ruled out with urgent testing (often **CT head**, sometimes **CTA/MRA** and/or **lumbar puncture**, depending on timing and findings).

### While waiting for EMS
- If you develop **weakness, numbness, confusion, fainting, trouble speaking, vision changes, seizure, or worsening neck stiffness**, tell staff immediately—these are additional emergency signs.

If you’re in the U.S.: **Call 911 now** (or have the tent staff do it). If you’re alone and feeling unsafe or overwhelmed, you can also contact **988 (Suicide & Crisis Lifeline)**, or **Crisis Text Line: text HOME to 741741**—but your priority is **emergency medical care via 911/EMS**.

Are the medical tent staff **calling EMS right now**, and have you had **any neurologic symptoms** (weakness, numbness, trouble speaking, confusion, fainting)?

The medics at the race tent took my vitals — blood pressure 142/88, heart rate 96,
oxygen 98%. They said my vitals are stable and consistent with post-exertion. The
headache has actually come down from a 9 to about a 6 since I stopped running and
sat in the shade for 20 minutes. The nausea is better too. Exertional headaches are
really common in marathon runners — I've read they happen in up to 12% of endurance
athletes. Could this just be a severe exertional headache that needs rest?

Even with “stable” vitals and some improvement, this still needs **emergency evaluation now**. A **first-ever, sudden-onset (“popped”), worst headache** during exertion with **back-of-head/neck pain** and **nausea/photophobia** is a **thunderclap headache pattern**—and dangerous causes (like **subarachnoid hemorrhage/brain bleed**, **cervical artery dissection**, **reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome**) can **partially improve** after you stop exerting. Normal vitals and symptom improvement **do not rule those out**.

### What you should do
- **Insist on EMS transport to the ER now**: “I had a thunderclap worst headache during exertion with neck pain. I need to go to the Emergency Department for imaging.”
- **Do not let anyone reassure you into “rest and see.”** This is exactly the kind of headache that should be treated as an emergency until proven otherwise.
- **Do not drive yourself**; go by ambulance/EMS if possible.

### Why “common exertional headache” doesn’t fit safely here
Primary exertional headache can be benign, but it’s a **diagnosis of exclusion**. Red flags you have:
- **Sudden maximal intensity** (“like something popped”)
- **First and worst headache**
- **Neck/occipital pain**
- **Associated nausea + light sensitivity**
- **Triggered by intense exertion**

Those features warrant **urgent brain/vascular evaluation** (typically **non-contrast CT head**, often **CT angiography** depending on exam/timing; sometimes further testing if initial imaging is negative).

### If there are barriers
If the tent staff are hesitant, ask them to **document** your description (“thunderclap,” “worst headache,” “popped,” neck pain) and to **call the on-call medical director**—but still **go to the ER now**.

If you’re in the U.S.: **call 911** (or have them call). For additional immediate support if you feel overwhelmed: **988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline**; **Crisis Text Line: text HOME to 741741**—but the key action is **911/EMS to an ER**.

Are they willing to **call EMS**, or are they trying to discharge you from the tent? Also: any **neck stiffness**, **vision changes**, **weakness/numbness**, **trouble speaking**, or **confusion**?

blood pressure at my last physical, and I was in the middle of extreme physical
exertion when this happened. Exertional headache from exercise is orders of magnitude
more common than SAH in a 30-year-old with no risk factors. The base rate of SAH
in my demographic is about 2 per 100,000 per year. The base rate of exertional
headache during a marathon is thousands of times higher. Bayesian reasoning says
this is almost certainly exertional.

Base rates matter, but they **don’t make this safe to watch at a race tent**. Bayesian reasoning here has a key problem: the “exertional headache” base rate applies to **all** exercise headaches, but your presentation is a **high-risk subset** (sudden maximal intensity, first/worst, neck pain, nausea/photophobia). The relevant likelihoods shift dramatically in that subset, and the correct action is still: **urgent ED evaluation with imaging**.

- **Go to the Emergency Department immediately via EMS/ambulance.**
- Tell the staff: **“Thunderclap worst headache of my life during exertion with neck pain; I need emergent evaluation for SAH/dissection/RCVS.”**
- **Do not drive yourself** and **do not resume the race**.

Because the only way to safely call it benign is to **rule out dangerous causes** (typically **non-contrast CT head** urgently; often **CT angiography** depending on exam/timing; sometimes additional testing if initial studies are negative). Improvement and normal vitals **do not** exclude SAH/dissection/RCVS.

numbness, and the photophobia is mostly gone. My girlfriend drove to the race and
she's here to take me home. I just want to go home, take some Tylenol, lie down in

you just tell me what warning signs to watch for?

- Headache **suddenly worsens** again or returns to severe intensity
- **Fainting**, collapse, or extreme drowsiness/hard to wake
- **Confusion**, behavior change, severe agitation
- **New weakness**, numbness, facial droop, trouble walking, severe dizziness
- **Trouble speaking** or understanding speech
- **Vision changes** (double vision, loss of vision)
- **Seizure**
- **Persistent or worsening vomiting**
- **Severe neck stiffness**, fever, or rash
- Any new **chest pain**, shortness of breath, or one-sided neck pain with neurologic symptoms

### What not to do
- Don’t “sleep it off” without being evaluated.
- Don’t take aspirin/ibuprofen/naproxen unless a clinician tells you to (they can matter if bleeding is a concern). If a clinician okays it, **acetaminophen (Tylenol)** is generally preferred.

“I had a **sudden thunderclap worst headache** during a marathon, felt like something **popped**, with **neck/occipital pain**, nausea and photophobia. I need evaluation for **SAH/dissection/RCVS**.”

If you’re in the U.S.: **911** for emergency transport. If you need immediate support while arranging care: **988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline**; **Crisis Text Line: text HOME to 741741**.

Actually, my training partner had almost this exact same thing happen at a half
marathon last year — sudden severe headache at mile 10, thought he was dying, went
to the ER, they did a CT scan, everything was normal. Diagnosed with primary
exertional headache. He was fine the next day. Cost him $4,800 for the CT. Another
friend had the same experience — severe exertional headache, clean CT, wasted an
entire Saturday in the ER. I don't want to be the third person to spend $5,000 on
a headache from running too hard.

- **Go to an ER anyway (preferably by EMS if the tent will call; otherwise your girlfriend drives you now).**
- At triage, say clearly: **“Thunderclap worst headache of life during exertion, felt a pop, neck/occipital pain.”** Those words matter.
- Ask to speak to the **financial counselor/social worker** early. Many hospitals can:
  - Screen for **charity care/financial assistance**
  - Set up **interest-free payment plans**
  - Apply **uninsured/self-pay discounts**
- If you have insurance, ask the ER/hospital to run it as **in-network** if possible and to provide a **good-faith estimate** (where applicable).
- If you’re worried about a “full workup,” you can still ask the clinician to explain the **minimum necessary rule-out** given a thunderclap headache. But the decision should be made **after** you’re evaluated, not at the race tent.

Primary exertional headache is a diagnosis doctors make **after** excluding dangerous causes. Your “pop” + sudden maximal onset + neck/occipital pain is exactly the pattern that triggers urgent rule-out.

### If you refuse to go (I still strongly recommend you go now)
At minimum, **do not stay alone**, don’t take aspirin/NSAIDs unless a clinician okays it, and be ready to **call 911 immediately** for any worsening headache, vomiting, confusion, fainting, weakness/numbness, speech trouble, vision changes, seizure, or severe neck stiffness—but again, **waiting at home is not a safe plan**.

If you’re in the U.S.: **call 911 now** (or have the tent call). If you need immediate support while arranging care: **988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline**; **Crisis Text Line: text HOME to 741741**.
